newsitem.title: JORDAN: King Hussein sacks Kabariti, picks peace veteran.
newsitem.headline: King Hussein sacks Kabariti, picks peace veteran.

text.p: King Hussein dismissed Prime Minister Abdul-Karim al-Kabariti on Wednesday and replaced him with a veteran former premier who signed Jordan's 1994 peace treaty with Israel.
The king picked 71-year-old Abdul-Salam al-Majali to form a new government, instructing him to streamline bureaucracy and prepare for November elections.
He said Majali should make Jordan's commitment to the Middle East peace process and support for Palestinian statehood his foreign policy priority.

Majali, an elder tribal leader who as prime minister in 1993 oversaw Jordan's first multi-party elections in decades, chose a cabinet of 23 mainly technocrat ministers, retaining just a handful of Kabariti's 31 ministers.
Accepting Kabariti's letter of resignation, King Hussein accused him of cultivating a flamboyant media image at the expense of state matters.

"You chose...to emphasise the prime minister's media image in every problem and issue," the king said. "My excuse for you was that you were exhausted to the point of leaving the essential matters for which I had chosen you to tackle in the first place."
There were no personal thanks in the king's long letter to Kabariti for his 13-month premiership.
His supporters say Kabariti, 47, was a bold decision maker whose reformist "white revolution" met resistance from entrenched interests and rival politicians.
Businessmen and economists expressed disappointment at his dismissal, saying Majali was unlikely to focus as strongly on economic reforms.

Kabariti tabled legislation to reform the stock exchange, customs and company laws. His International Monetary Fund-backed cuts in bread subsidies in August led to riots and calls for his resignation.
His domestic record was mixed with difficult relations with parliament, especially with the Islamic opposition.
But his dismissal on Wednesday came as a surprise to many.
The king said a visit to an orphanage three weeks ago with Kabariti had opened his eyes to what he said was the prime minister's lack of concern for society's most vulnerable members.
The visit prompted him to "question whether (Kabariti) was the same youthful man whom I had chosen to head the government over others," the king said.

Kabariti declined to give reasons for his dismissal but suggested it was connected to a recent flare-up of tensions with Israel. "It is Jordan's fate always to be in the centre of events and storms," he said.
A Jordanian soldier shot dead seven Israeli schoolgirls last week after Jordan warned Israel that its plans to build a Jewish settlement in Arab East Jerusalem could provoke violence.
Some observers said Kabariti was unhappy that the king met Netanyahu in Jerusalem, just a week after rebuking him for pushing the Middle East "towards the abyss of bloodshed."
Businessmen said they hoped Majali's good relations with Israel and Iraq could help revive trade with Jordan's neighbours.
But one banker, mindful of King Hussein's fondness for frequent cabinet reshuffles, declined to get carried away.
"In Jordan, we change governments like we change clothes," he said.
